page.title: 02THE PENNINE FOOTHILLS
page.content: The eastern two thirds of the block is an upland plateau of Coal Measure rock about 350m high,covered in moor and marsh until modern agricultural techniques made it productive grazing land with only the odd patch of original cover.To the west the ground scarps steeply to the sheltered stream valleys first carved by glaciers and now occupied by the villages of Hepworth and Jackson Bridge.Long association with the wool industry is evidenced by the weaver's cottages and mill sites, where the soft and plentiful water encouraged the industry's growth. The hillside above Jackson Bridge was mined for coal and fire clay and led to the foundation of the Hepworth Iron and Coal Company.Now dormitory development of the villages has taken over while the land is farmed ever more intensively.
